ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: this course if very valuable because teaches hands on skills applicable to many interests and disciplines seeking to utilize geographic information systems.

Question 10Dana was fantastic. He made a 3 hour lecture on a computer program interesting and engaging. He was endlessly patient, accessible and understanding. He built a class that provided the opportunity to learn but he was accommodating of and made allowances for the fact that we all had other responsibilities that sometimes got in the way without compromising our experience in the class.

Dana's responsiveness to student comments (via Piazza, the online web platform, and via email) is unsurpassed. This class was excellent, and it was easy to ask questions and learn a ton about GIS. Also, Meredith Azevedo was a great teaching assistant!
A great class! Even if you don't really think mapping is your thing, it's a good skill to have, and Dana is great.

Explanations and analogies were clear and easy to understand, and the handouts were useful. Maybe an alphabetical index to accompany the handouts would be useful, so one could more easily locate a particular tool.

I don't expect to ever be an expert in GIS. But following my summer internship, I have a much better appreciation of the drive for "interdisciplinary" skills. It's obvious that we need to have more and more knowledge on all sorts of topics. And the ability to create visual explanations for others can be incredibly valuable. I highly recommend that other students take one or more GIS classes... and take them with Dana. He's a fantastic teacher. He's incredibly knowledgeable and articulate.
Question 9. the instructor was responsive to the questions of the students but he is sarcastic in his habit to answer the questions.

Dana Tomlin is a fabulous professor. The assignments are very useful, and I learned a lot in this class and implemented the learning right away in other courses and projects. I'm so glad I took this class- I think it's one of the best FES offers.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Learning a useful and marketable skill.
The handouts are better than any textbook I've seen on GIS. The tutorials and assignments were well-designed and I do feel like I have learned a lot.
You learn very practical skills and working with GIS is a lot of fun.
enjoyed the final project using my own data.
Dana Tomlin.
I loved the final project, even if I did spent several solid days in the computer lab. Class was also fun, and I especially like the day we "ranked" our peers' posters.
Professor's capacity to explain difficult concepts.
Dana's teaching style.
knowledge about GIS in general and how we may be able to use the knowledge in our work.
Professor Dana has the amazing ability to explain abstract ideas in a very vivid way with lots of metaphors.
The course readings and materials.
It was fun to try out different tools and to work on different projects. While working on a term project was initially daunting, it ended up being pretty cool.
Learning the concepts / intuition behind GIS from Dana.
Weekly assignments
exercises though time consuming

The way the professor explains how different GIS tools work is outstanding. He really makes an effort to explain in the simplest of manners.The homework's really ties the material covered in class together.The TA was able to explain everything in a clear manner and provided you with great guidance to do the homework's and the final project.I was really happy with the peer-based grading system. Besides allowing you to see how your classmates work, it encourages you to do better.

I liked the variety of assignments, which allowed for an opportunity to learn basics of GIS and to have some fun, but also were clearly applicable to real problems you might face/questions you might answer as a GIS user.
Dana and the assignments. The ability to work on our own topic for the final project.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Some of the lectures were slow / too much time to get into the actual material in class

I did not feel like I got appropriate amounts of feedback about my work. When you're expected to send 6 hours a week on your assignments (and sometimes more), it would be nice to have some kind of feedback. In this semester, which the professor said was experimental, students gave each other feedback for the first few assignments. Then we stopped getting feedback even from each other. We were instructed to look at the work of our peers to "see where we stand" in the course. Direct questions about how we were progressing in the course were ignored and again we were told to just look at the work of our peers.I did not like this at all. It was one thing to have the blind leading the blind and having us give each other comments, but by fall break we were receiving no comments at all. It really seemed like the professor was just trying to get out of the work of grading our assignments. Perhaps there are simply too many students between the Yale and Penn students in the same course, but then why take on so many students? Or, if you really want to teach this many students, use your TAs. Have them help give comments but do SOMETHING so that students can get feedback on their work. If you expect your students to work for so many hours a week, the least you can do is tell them something about the quality of their work.I honestly can't tell where I stand in the course now. I have no idea. The only grade in the entire course is a final project. This is extremely stressful and completely unnecessary. In a separate issue, the professor really liked to spring assignments on students that weren't in the syllabus and announced them much too late for students to plan around their other coursework. This included assignments that were due over academic breaks and assigned after many students had already left town. I was going to take the raster course in the spring but there is no way that I'm putting myself through so much work and stress for such a low return again. It really felt like Tomlin did not respect his students at all.
The pace of each lesson could be picked up a bit.

Grading needs to be figured out and transparent. It's fine if everything is based on the final project, but if that is the case, Dana should provide feedback on every assignment as a matter of course.It's frustrating using so many different platforms for the class. We had to use a non-yale gmail account, use drive, V2 was not used, then there piazza for questions and resources. I was just very confusing. I understand if you can't use V2 because you want to integrate the classes, but whatever the solution, it should be better integrated

A little more feedback on weekly assignments would have been helpful. Even though I was able to compare my work to that of my peers, sometimes I wondered if I was missing something obvious, or if what I actually did was done in the most efficient way possible.
This class needs more TAs.

There is focus on one software, ArcGIS and not the concept of GIS in particular given the numerous software available in the market. I feel that it may have been helpful to show situations where each of the skills and features will have been helpful first and not the other way around.This was not in any way introductory GIS.
None that i can think of.
I think having a little more feedback on the homework would have been helpful.
Requires more teaching assistances and group lab schedules to allow students to work together but independently.

I'm not sure how it could be improved. Dana's set it up so that it runs like clockwork and he provides fantastic guidance. My only preference would be for two 1.5 hr classes per week, but that's not about to happen... and it would still be great for others to take his class.
Grading system must consider weekly assignments. Rather focus on final project.

although instructor is trying to test different ways of grading the students i think grading only the final assignment is not adequate. grades should be based on the weekly assignments and also the final project and only on the final project.
Having absolutely no feedback from the professor for the whole year makes it hard for you to know how are you doing.

I do wish that we had a bit more feedback on individual assignments from Dana. I liked how the course was set up with us evaluating each other's work and learning from what others did (more realistic than usual course setup), but would have been good to get some more insights from the professional's eye.
The grading system was a disaster and was continually in flux. Additionally, the inclusion of an arbitrary early deadline for the final homework as a personal joke was not amusing.
I don't think anything!

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Directly related
n/a
N/A
The relationship between assignments and class was great.
There were no lab/discussion sections for the course, which will have been helpful given the need to fully understand the features of the software.
The discussion generally happens online and in some sense it's more effective as an open forum saves a lot of time.
Dana is a master, including his notes that make the class possible.
we did not have discussion but had group project.
N/A

We didn't have discussion sections, but we did have office hours with Meredith. She was an amazing TA and if there is a teaching award I could nominate both Dana and Meredith for, I would in a heartbeat.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It builds my skill set and gives me another tool for problem-solving and analysis
I need to know GIS because I work in conservation. Mapping is crucial and one of the few universally marketable skills you can learn at FES.
i will use tools learned in this class in my masters research project.
I'm still not certain how GIS will fit into my research and career, but I am very glad to have it in my toolbelt.

GIS relates to my program because I'm focused on the physical landscape, and it is incredibly helpful to illustrate what I'm talking about. Also, I anticipate that having GIS skills will help me land a job, since it was something I felt I was lacking before FES.
A necessary element in general Land-use management planning.

My research involves reforestation and forest degradation and deforestation. These topics involve understanding of the spatial considerations and extent of the problems. Thus knowing and having the skills on GIS will be very valuable even if I do not directly engage in a career in GIS.
This course hones my skill in GIS as a tool to solve the problem in my field.

GIS as a tool is becoming a major decision making tool across sectors in todays world. the course provided me with a understanding of how the system actually works and how powerful it is in providing a basis for decision making.

I hope that I might use GIS in future work relating to urban planning or environmental management, but at this point I don't see an immediate application. I definitely want to use GIS in my professional life though!

I'm not looking to gain qualitative / soft skills at FES. I'm interested in gaining quantitative / hard skills. I like the information analysis classes. GIS is a great tool to present quantitative results.

As a forester, I deal with data collection in the field and I should be able to represent geographically what I do, forest types, soils, topography ... In addition, the information collected must be analyzed and presented in such a way that people understand where it was collected, in which scale and what are the major findings. I have learned how to collect data or to hunt for data, to analyze geographic data and to present.
i have learned new subject and perfectly fits my interest on GIS.
GIS is essential for so many of the jobs I am applying for.
Ability to analyze data in different ways and to present it visually.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To learn the ArcGIS software
I needed to learn GIS.
to learn ArcGIS.
Because I wanted to learn GIS
I had done a little bit of work with maps previously and I wanted to improve my skills. I definitely accomplished that.
As mentioned above, to gain a skill, to help me get a job in the future, and to complement my program of study.
To better understand the applications of ArcGis.
Because I had no previous GIS experience, and I felt it was an important skill to have at least a basic grasp of.
I do not have any GIS background so this is helpful to understand new research that requires spatial understanding of the scope of problems that are very relevant currently.
Solidify my skills in GIS and also Dana is a very knowledgeable professor.
To be introduced to the field of Arc GIS in management.
Wanted to work on a skill (rather than subject knowledge), wanted to use a different part of my brain, wanted to embrace technology as part of the toolkit for solving environmental problems.
Information analysis and presentation skills.
Very important as I am interested in landscape management.
i am interested to learn GIS and its applications.
I wanted to gain the necessary skills to work with ArcGIS. It think having an ability to graphically display information is a great skill to have.
To learn gis
Data analytics and a desire to learn hard skills.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes

I learned a lot, but again I thought the way that the course was taught, at least in terms of grading and feedback, was absurd. If I could have just had the handouts and assignments I would have been happier learning the material on my own.
Yes, the knowledge and skills that I gained met my expectations, although having taken the spring (raster) course, I do not think taking both are completely necessary.
Mostly
yes, exceeded my expectations.
yes
Yes. It's a lot to learn and it will take practice and I will probably lose a lot of it, but I am really glad that I took it.
YES!
Yes, far and beyond.
Yes!
Not completely. I feel again very strongly that a lab/discussion section will have been more helpful to maximize the skills and knowledge of the TA.
Yes.
Yes. This was by far one of the most exciting course i have taken.
Yes
Yes, though they exceeded my expectations. Not only is Dana great, but he always got me excited and thinking about new approaches to solving problems.
Yes!
yes, it was a new learning for me.
Yes, very much.
Yes. I am amazed comparing my final project to my earlier work.
Yes.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

The different skills and knowledge of my teammate was very valuable in addressing the requirements of the assignments given the need to submit requirements regularly. The nature of the assignments require an understanding of what was taught in the preceding session of the course that classmates who may for one reason or another, could not attend are able to ask the TA or classmates for help.

Advantages: Sometimes one partner could see potential solutions to a problem that the other had not seen. It would help you push each other.Disadvantages: Coordinating schedules, having different preferences on layout and how much explanation to provide. Also, I need to click through the operations to feel like I'm internalizing them, so the fact that it's most efficient for only one person to do the clicking is another disadvantage.
interesting to work together but difficult to get along because we tend to defend our points.
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Think very carefully. It's a ton of work every week (including over breaks!) and if Tomlin chooses to teach it the same way next time it will be very frustrating. If he has the only grade as the final project and the weekly assignments assessed by your peers again, you may not want to bother. I had been planning on taking Tomlin's Raster course in the spring but I won't be because I found this style of feedback so discouraging.
take it and plan to put a significant amount of effort in.
Take the class if you want to learn GIS. The class is awesome!

Do it. It's a lot of work and it's FRUSTRATING and tedious, but totally worth it and the whole course is oriented towards building a usable applicable skill set for you to apply to your own area of interest.
Do it! The format this semester, with grading based on the final project, makes the week to week work less weighty and relieves some of the pressure.
Take full advantage of Ta hours, and also use Piazza.

I think it's a great class. You spend a lot of time on the homework assignments, but you also learn a lot doing so. Dana is a great instructor, and it's fun that you get to chose something meaningful to you (if you wish) for your final project. I wouldn't say that I'm fluent in GIS now, but I at least have a grasp of the language.
That the course is not in any way an introduction to GIS. That there is at least some understanding of the concepts and the application of the course.
Start to prepare for your final project as early as possible.
Go for it, and give yourself enough time to complete assignments in a relaxed way, so that you can try out different things, instead of rushing to get to the right answer.
Students should have strong motivation to study GIS.

Take it! I've had some classmates tell me that they could teach themselves GIS (I suppose, but it's time-consuming) and others say there are others to do mapping for them. I appreciate their thoughts, but in a fast-paced environment, if you can't do it yourself... you may need to wait until someone else has free time. That could be a problem.My goal was not to become an expert. My goal was to get a sense of how to use GIS so that I could do some rudimentary maps to give others a sense of how to visualize something. Then if others feel it's worthwhile, someone else could create a better map.
They should do take the class, very important for their own work.
it is an interesting course if one is interested to learn GIS.

Take it,you won't regret it. The classes are fun, the professor is great explaining and is available for any questions you may have during the whole semester, and even when sometimes the homework's and the final project can be demanding, you learn a lot from them.

Definitely devote at least six hours to weekly projects. Even if you are just problem solving for 5 out of those 6 hours, you will become so much more comfortable with the software and learn things that you never knew would come in handy. Overall a great course--my favorite this semester.
Take it
Take it! Keep in mind the workload is demanding, but Dana is very flexible which is great.
